metadata.case_name: Madhya Pradesh Industries Ltd. v. Union of India & Ors.

facts.text: On February 5, 1941, Rai Bahadur Bansilal Abirchand took a lease of 216 acres 92 cents in Government Forest, East Pench Range, Tahsil Ramtek, District Nagpur, from Governor of Central Provinces and Berar for 15 years commencing September 10, 1940.
Under indenture dated March 4, 1952, appellant obtained transfer of the leasehold interest from successors of Bansilal Abirchand and entered possession, spending about Rs. 10,00,000 for development.
Lease expired on September 9, 1955; appellant applied for renewal for 20 years to Secretary, Commerce and Industries Department, Madhya Pradesh.
After correspondence, offer on special duty, Industries and Co-operation Department, State of Bombay, informed appellant by letter dated September 2, 1958, that renewal would not be granted.
Appellant's revision against that order dismissed by Central Government on December 14, 1958.
On April 9, 1959, State of Bombay issued notification calling for applications for lease of the mines.
Appellant filed application for 20-year lease on May 15, 1959.
Government of Bombay granted entire area to appellant by order dated July 8, 1959, informed by letter July 14, 1959.
In 1960, territories divided; mines fell in Maharashtra State.
On August 25, 1960, Maharashtra Government notified mines reserved for public sector exploitation.
Collector of Nagpur informed appellant on January 16, 1961, that application rejected as mines reserved for State exploitation.
Appellant filed revision to Central Government on March 11, 1961.
Central Government on June 22, 1961, instructed Maharashtra to reconsider application.
Maharashtra Government rejected application by letter dated December 19, 1961.
Appellant filed revision to Central Government on February 17, 1962.
Central Government rejected revision on October 17, 1964.
Subsequently, Maharashtra issued notification dated March 26, 1965, inviting applications; appellant submitted application.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Central Government's order rejecting revision is bad for lack of reasons.
Whether principles of natural justice violated by denying personal hearing and considering extraneous matters without opportunity.
Whether Central Government ignored prior grant by Bombay and failed to comply with s.17 of the Act for public sector reservation.

petitioner_arguments.text: Order bad as judicial order without reasons.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 136 Constitution; Mineral Concession Rules r.55

petitioner_arguments.text: Violated natural justice: no personal hearing despite request; considered extraneous matters without opportunity.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Principles of natural justice; r.55 proviso

petitioner_arguments.text: Illegal as ignored final order granting lease by Bombay; could not reserve for public sector without s.17 compliance.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Mines and Minerals Act s.17; s.8(2)

respondent_arguments.text: Not fit case for Art.136 exercise as fresh applications called and appellant applied.
Central Government order gave reasons by stating no valid ground for interference, agreeing with State reasons.

court_reasoning.text: Central Government acts judicially as tribunal under r.55; must give reasons for orders appealable under Art.136 to exclude arbitrariness.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Reasoned order essential for welfare state, judicial scrutiny.

court_reasoning.text: No right to personal hearing; written representation suffices; no proof extraneous matter not noticed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Opportunity under r.55 met by written reps.

court_reasoning.text: Bombay order not final grant without Central approval under s.8(2); s.17 inapplicable as no Central Govt mining proposal.
Bachawat J.: Central order sufficiently reasoned by referencing State order and no valid ground; not bound to repeat reasons.

holdings.text: Central Government exercising revisional power under r.55 acts judicially and should give reasons.
No entitlement to personal hearing; natural justice satisfied.
Bombay 1959 order not valid grant without Central approval; s.17 inapplicable.
Not fit case for interference under Art.136 given fresh applications process.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shivji Nathubhai v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Central Govt under Mineral Concession Rules acts judicially as tribunal.

precedents_cited.case_name: Harinagar Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Shyam Sundar Jhunjhunwala
precedents_cited.relevance: Tribunal must give reasons for orders appealable under Art.136.

statutes_cited.name: Mines and Minerals (Regulation and Development) Act, 1957
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs grant of mining leases, prior approval for manganese, revision powers.

statutes_cited.name: Mineral Concession Rules, 1960
statutes_cited.relevance: Procedure for refusal communication, revision application and disposal by Central Govt.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed as not fit for interference under Art.136 given fresh application process; no costs.

key_quotes.text: The condition to give reasons introduces clarity and excludes or at any rate minimises arbitrariness.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Subba Rao J. on necessity of speaking orders by tribunals.

key_quotes.text: A speaking order will at its best be a reasonable and at its worst be at least a plausible one.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Emphasizes restraint on abuse of power.

key_quotes.text: The revision application was rejected, because the Central Government agreed with the reasons given by the State Government.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Bachawat J. holding order sufficiently reasoned.
